docs.lead_paragraph: Being overweight is known to be associated with Type 2 diabetes, the disease that generally begins in adulthood. But new research suggests that it may also hasten the onset of Type 1 diabetes, which usually occurs in children and young adults. As obesity becomes an increasingly serious public health problem for Americans of all ages, the incidence of Type 2 diabetes has increased. Its rising incidence in children has been especially troubling.
docs.abstract: Type 2 diabetes has been on rise in United States along with obesity; researchers report in journal Diabetes Care that type 1 diabetes can also be linked with excess body weight; British study holds that overweight children develop type 1 diabetes earlier than those who are normal weight; Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh finds similar relationship, hypothesizing that excess weight requires pancreas to make more insulin and therefore wear out insulin-producing cells faster (S)
docs.snippet: Being overweight is known to be associated with Type 2 diabetes, the disease that generally begins in adulthood. But new research suggests that it may also hasten the onset of Type 1 diabetes, which usually occurs in children and young adults.    As...

docs.lead_paragraph: People who use Medicaid or have no health insurance are much more likely to die from aneurysms in the abdominal aorta than people with private insurance, researchers report. Writing in the journal Surgery, the researchers said that in people without private insurance the disorder is more likely to be overlooked.
docs.abstract: University of Michigan researchers Dr Gilbert R Upchurch Jr and Dr Leslie K Boxer find patients without health insurance are more likely to die from aneurysms in abdominal aorta than those who are covered; theorize people with good insurance are more likely to have problems discovered during routine visits for variety of ailments; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: People who use Medicaid or have no health insurance are much more likely to die from aneurysms in the abdominal aorta than people with private insurance, researchers report.    Writing in the journal Surgery, the researchers said that in people...

docs.lead_paragraph: Deanna Friedman began worrying when her daughter was not crawling by 11 months. ''They said I was being a paranoid first-time-around mother,'' she recalled. ''But I just knew something wasn't right.'' By 14 months, her daughter, Samantha, was still not mobile, but doctors told her parents that babies could walk as late as 18 months. Samantha began showing other symptoms, too. She was lethargic. She had an enlarged toe, but doctors said it could be a fluke that no one had noticed before.

headline.main: Drugs Show Promise in Children With Arthritis

docs.abstract: Biologics, new class of arthritis drugs, are giving hope to people suffering from severe forms of illness; 10-year-old Samantha Friedman describes substantial relief from her polyarticular arthritis after taking biologic called Enbrel; long-term effects of drugs, which mimic natural TNF receptor proteins inside body in order to reduce inflammation, and effects of drugs on patient immune systems are unknown; major types of juvenile arthritis discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Deanna Friedman began worrying when her daughter was not crawling by 11 months. ''They said I was being a paranoid first-time-around mother,'' she recalled. ''But I just knew something wasn't right.''     By 14 months, her daughter, Samantha, was...

docs.lead_paragraph: Crying furiously, Carl Aguirre grabbed the hand that reached out to soothe him and shoved it away. His twin, Clarence, glassy-eyed and coughing from a cold, chimed in and began crying, too. But when their mother, Arlene Aguirre, offered bottles of formula, they snatched the bottles and quieted down instantly.

headline.main: Two Boys, Joined Skulls, One Goal: Two Lives

docs.abstract: 18-month-old conjoined twins Carl Aguirre and Clarence Aguirre arrive from Philippines and prepare for surgery to separate them; Dr James Goodrich of Montefiore Medical Center (Bronx, NY) leads team that expects to perform first surgery around October 2003; boys are joined at head and although they have separate brains they share major veins, which require multistage operations to reroute vital circulatory functions; mother Arlene Aguirre says that although she was not aware she was carrying conjoined twins until she was in her fourth month, she would not have considered terminating pregnancy; conjoined twins occur more often in developing nations where prenatal care is limited; many parents, given advanced warning of conjoined twins through ultrasound, choose to terminate pregnancy; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Crying furiously, Carl Aguirre grabbed the hand that reached out to soothe him and shoved it away. His twin, Clarence, glassy-eyed and coughing from a cold, chimed in and began crying, too.    But when their mother, Arlene Aguirre, offered bottles of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Tobacco-related diseases are still the leading cause of preventable death in women, and most states are not meeting the nation's goals to discourage women from smoking, according to a report released today by the National Women's Law Center and Oregon Health and Science University. Thirty-nine states earned a failing grade when judged by a list of criteria from the Department of Health and Human Services and on the strength of their tobacco control policies. The nation over all also earned a failing grade.

headline.main: States Fail to Meet No-Smoking Goals for Women

docs.abstract: Dr Michelle Berlin, Oregon Health and Science University Center for Women's Health researcher, discusses study she led along with National Women's Law Center, in which they graded state's efforts to curb smoking by women; study gives failing grade to 39 states and not one state earns satisfactory rating when judged by Department of Health and Human Services list of criteria; lung cancer passed breast cancer as leading cause of death in women in 1987; state history of tobacco production and cultural distinctions offer some reasons why certain states fair better than others in reducing habit; ratings are based in part on policies that encourage women to quit or never to start; map; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Tobacco-related diseases are still the leading cause of preventable death in women, and most states are not meeting the nation's goals to discourage women from smoking, according to a report released today by the National Women's Law Center and...

docs.lead_paragraph: For all that has been written and spoken about addiction as a medical disease, most people, including most physicians, understand little about what draws people to drugs and keeps them hooked, often despite severe consequences and repeated attempts to quit. A better understanding of the pull and tug of addiction can help those who are hooked and those who want the monkey off their backs for good.

headline.main: Addiction: A Brain Ailment, Not a Moral Lapse

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column explains how addiction causes biological changes within human brain that effect ability to recover and give up drug; contends that addiction is brain disease that causes chronic mental illness and requires treatment strategies that go beyond cessation of substance abuse; New England Journal of Medicine report, by Barcelona (Spain) Drs Jordi Cami and Magi Farre, describes adaptive changes within central nervous system that support concept that addiction itself is not behavioral, even though many people begin to use drugs for social or behavioral reasons; holds certain personality traits and mental disorders can increase likelihood of becoming addict; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: For all that has been written and spoken about addiction as a medical disease, most people, including most physicians, understand little about what draws people to drugs and keeps them hooked, often despite severe consequences and repeated attempts...

docs.lead_paragraph: When elderly people have problems with falling, the cause is less likely to be any medications they are taking than any of a number of common chronic diseases, a new study reports. Writing in BMJ, a British medical journal, researchers from the University of Bristol point to several medical problems that appear to play roles in falls among the elderly. Among them are circulatory disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, depression and arthritis. The findings suggest that doctors may want to broaden their attention to include not just the numerous prescription drugs elderly people take but other health factors.

headline.main: Disease Is Often at Fault in Falls

docs.abstract: University of Bristol researchers, writing in BMJ, British medical journal, find that chronic disease plays greater role in falls for older adults than any medications they may be taking; 17 percent of women who are between 60 and 79 report having fallen at least once in past 12 months and three-quarters of those women suffer from chronic diseases; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: When elderly people have problems with falling, the cause is less likely to be any medications they are taking than any of a number of common chronic diseases, a new study reports.    Writing in BMJ, a British medical journal, researchers from the...

docs.lead_paragraph: My symptoms were hardly exotic: mild vertigo, a touch of indigestion, light-headedness, not exactly grounds for an all points bulletin. I was sure it was only a virus and I knew the drill: rest, drink plenty of fluids and this too shall pass. It did not. Waves of fatigue washed over me and catnaps punctuated my day. This gave me pause, but only briefly. Work was the culprit, I insisted. Who would not be exhausted after long days of meetings and memos and sprinting between offices?

headline.main: Paying Heed To Problems Of the Heart

docs.abstract: Cases article focuses on symptoms of heart disease in women and variety of reasons why they go unnoticed by patients and physicians; urges women and medical community to refocus efforts on reducing nation's top killer of women, which claims 500,000 lives each year (M)
docs.snippet: My symptoms were hardly exotic: mild vertigo, a touch of indigestion, light-headedness, not exactly grounds for an all points bulletin. I was sure it was only a virus and I knew the drill: rest, drink plenty of fluids and this too shall pass. It did...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Lung Cancer: Myths, Facts, Choices -- and Hope,'' by Dr. Claudia I. Henschke and Peggy McCarthy, with Sarah Wernick. W. W. Norton, $26.95. ''Life and Breath: Preventing, Treating and Reversing Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease,'' by Dr. Neil Schachter. Broadway Books, $24.95.
docs.abstract: Dr Claudia I Henschke and Sarah Wernick book Lung Cancer; Myths, Facts, Choices--and Hope, explores hopeful side of disease that is now leading cancer killer for women and carries five-year survival rate of only 14 percent; holds that early detection and appropriate treatment can improve quality of and extend life for those diagnosed with lung cancer; book Life and Breath: Preventing, Treating and Reversing Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease by Dr Neil Schachter outlines fourth leading cause of death in United States and urges preventive measures, like increased antioxidants, for health; acknowledges that illness would probably not exist without epidemic of smoking; photos (M)
docs.snippet: ''Lung Cancer: Myths, Facts, Choices -- and Hope,'' by Dr. Claudia I. Henschke and Peggy McCarthy, with Sarah Wernick. W. W. Norton, $26.95.    ''Life and Breath: Preventing, Treating and Reversing Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease,'' by Dr. Neil...

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: LUNG CANCER: MYTHS, FACTS, CHOICES--AND HOPE (BOOK)

docs.lead_paragraph: Stress tests are a well-established method for doctors to assess the risk of heart disease in men, but their effectiveness among women has been unclear. A new study suggests the tests can be effective for women, but with a twist.

headline.main: A Closer Look at Women's Hearts

docs.abstract: Dr Samia Mora and colleagues at Johns Hopkins University report in Journal of American Medical Association that using stress test to assess heart disease risk in women is ineffective; find that women's ability to exercise intensively and recovery time for heart from strenuous workout are much better indicators of cardiovascular health (S)
docs.snippet: Stress tests are a well-established method for doctors to assess the risk of heart disease in men, but their effectiveness among women has been unclear.    A new study suggests the tests can be effective for women, but with a twist.
